Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandmother for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my work, the clang of metal and shouts of my crew echoing in my ears. I know the drill—drop everything, head to the muster point, no exceptions. But just as I reach for my hard hat, my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s a message from my granddaughter: “Grandma, can I call you? I really need your advice. It’s important.” My heart twists. She never asks for help unless it’s serious. I picture her, anxious and alone, waiting for my wisdom, the way my own grandmother once comforted me. But the foreman’s voice booms, “Let’s go! No delays!” I’m torn—my team depends on me to follow protocol, to keep everyone safe. Yet my granddaughter needs me, right now, to be her anchor. The phone vibrates again, insistent. I stand frozen, caught between the urgent call of family and the unyielding demands of the job, my hands trembling as I weigh which part of myself to answer first.
